blocks.content:
In this quick start guide, you'll create a **Service Level Objective** (SLO) using a ratio query.

You'll learn how to:
- Define a service level indicator (SLI) with success and total metrics
- Set a target percentage and error budget
- Name and save your SLO

This takes about **3 minutes**.
Let's start by navigating to the SLO creation wizard.
The **service level indicator** (SLI) is the metric that measures how well your service is performing. You'll define it using a **ratio query** — dividing successful events by total events.
The **time window** sets the evaluation period for your SLO. The default of 30 days works well for most use cases.
blocks.tooltip: Leave this at 30 days for a standard SLO evaluation window.

blocks.content: Select the **Ratio** query type. This lets you define success and total event metrics separately — the most common way to measure an SLI.
blocks.tooltip: Ratio queries compare successful events against total events.

blocks.content:
Enter the **success metric** — a PromQL query that counts successful events.

This example counts HTTP requests with 2xx status codes.
blocks.tooltip: This query measures the rate of successful HTTP responses.

blocks.content:
Enter the **total metric** — a PromQL query that counts all events.

This example counts all HTTP requests regardless of status code.
blocks.tooltip: This query measures the rate of all HTTP requests.

blocks.content: Click **Run queries** to preview the results and verify your metrics are returning data.
blocks.tooltip: Validates that your PromQL queries return data.

blocks.content: Click **Set target and error budget** to proceed to the next step.

blocks.title: Set the target and error budget

blocks.content: The **target** is the percentage of requests that should succeed. The **error budget** is calculated automatically as the remaining percentage — the amount of failure you can tolerate.
Enter **99.9** as the target percentage. This means 99.9% of requests should succeed, leaving a 0.1% error budget.
blocks.tooltip: A 99.9% target is a common starting point for web services.

blocks.content: Click **Add name and description** to continue.
Give your SLO a clear, descriptive name. This appears on dashboards and in alert rules.
blocks.tooltip: Choose a name that identifies the service and what's being measured.

blocks.targetvalue: Measures the percentage of successful HTTP responses (2xx) across all services.
blocks.content: Add a description that explains what this SLO measures. This helps your team understand the SLO's purpose.
blocks.tooltip: A good description helps teammates understand what this SLO tracks.

blocks.content: Click **Add SLO alert rules** to continue. We'll skip optional fields like folder and labels for now.
SLO alerting notifies your team when the error budget is burning too fast. For this quick start, we'll skip alerts — you can enable them later.
The **Add SLO alert rules** checkbox enables burn-rate alerts. Leave it unchecked for now.
blocks.tooltip: You can enable alerts later by editing the SLO.

blocks.content: Click **Review SLO** to see a summary of your configuration.
Review your SLO configuration. You can click **Edit section** on any card to go back and make changes.
Everything looks good! Click **Save and view all SLOs** to create your SLO.
blocks.tooltip: This saves the SLO and starts generating recording rules.

blocks.content:
## What you've learned

- How to define an SLI using a **ratio query** with success and total metrics
- How to set an SLO **target** and understand error budgets
- How to **name and save** an SLO in Grafana

## Next steps

- **Enable alerts**: Edit your SLO to add burn-rate alert rules
- **Add labels**: Use `service_name` and `team_name` labels to organize SLOs
- **Explore dashboards**: View the auto-generated SLO dashboard to monitor performance
- **Create more SLOs**: Define SLOs for other critical service metrics
